title-group.article-title: Reply: ‘Obstructive sleep apnea is associated with fatigue in multiple sclerosis’ by Kaminska et al.

body.p: A number of factors may account for the difference in obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) prevalence between our study and that of Veauthier et al. It is noteworthy that our study was not designed to determine prevalence of OSA in multiple sclerosis (MS). Rather, the main objective was to evaluate the association between OSA and clinical symptoms. It is possible that differences in study populations accounted for a portion of the difference in OSA frequency. Subjects were, however, recruited irrespective of their sleep-related symptoms. The proportion completing the study from the number who were approached was smaller in our study than the study of Veauthier et al., 22.5% versus 47% (details regarding the number of patients approached are provided in the Results section of our manuscript). Therefore, it is possible that there may have been greater selection bias in our study population. Also, our subjects were slightly older (mean of 47.3 years versus 43.2 years in the polysomnography (PSG) group in the Veauthier study), a factor associated with increased OSA risk.

Technical differences may also explain some of the discrepancy in OSA prevalence. The use of home versus laboratory PSG should not have had a major impact on OSA prevalence,1,2 and both studies analyzed the second night to exclude first night effects. Both studies used the same criteria for scoring respiratory events (American Academy of Sleep Medicine (AASM) 1999), and both recorded respiratory airflow with pressure sensors. However, different criteria were used for sleep scoring (Rechtschaffen & Kales (R&K) versus AASM 2007). Moreover, those criteria were based on different EEG electrodes. In the study by Veauthier et al. scoring of sleep stages and cortical arousals is based on C3/C4 EEG electrodes, using R&K criteria. In our study, C4/C3/F3/F4/O1/O2 EEG electrodes were used. Central and occipital leads were used to score arousal, while also considering additional information detected on F3 or F4. Indeed, frontal EEG (F leads) has been found to be considerably more sensitive for arousal detection.3 Therefore, the use of the AASM 2007 recommended EEG recording and sleep scoring may result in detection of more arousal-associated respiratory events. In our study, in fact, the majority of respiratory events detected were hypopneas with arousal.

It could be argued that these events without associated hypoxemia are not clinically significant. However, we have found an important relation between severe fatigue and both the apnea–hypopnea index and the respiratory-related arousal index. In that fatigue is a major symptom in MS, this outcome-based finding supports the clinical relevance of hypopneas with arousal. In addition, in a non-randomized controlled study, we have found that fatigue improved significantly with OSA treatment using continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP).4,5 This preliminary intervention data further validates the scoring criteria we have used and supports the concept that sleep fragmentation associated with hypopnea is in fact an important determinant of fatigue in MS patients.
We thank Veauthier and colleagues for their discerning comments.
